questions.text: Acute sudden painful diminution of vision with vertically oval pupil is caused by: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Angle closure glaucoma

 

Angle closure glaucoma is a condition where there is a sudden increase in intraocular pressure (IOP) due to the closure of the angle between the iris and the cornea, which obstructs the drainage of aqueous humor. This leads to a rapid rise in IOP, resulting in acute, severe eye pain, headache, nausea, and a sudden loss of vision. A key clinical sign of an acute angle closure glaucoma attack is a mid-dilated, vertically oval, and sluggishly reacting pupil. The vertically oval pupil occurs due to ischemia of the iris sphincter muscles caused by the high IOP.

 

 

This condition is an ophthalmic emergency, and immediate treatment is necessary to prevent permanent vision loss. The high IOP can cause damage to the optic nerve, leading to irreversible vision loss if not promptly managed.

 

Note - Vogt's triad is a set of three clinical signs associated with the aftermath of an acute attack of glaucoma. This triad includes sphincter atrophy (damage to the iris sphincter muscle), a mid-dilated pupil that does not react well to light, and glaucoma flecken, which are patches of pigmentation or discoloration on the lens of the eye resulting from the damage caused by the increased intraocular pressure during a glaucoma attack.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CSR/Macular degeneration: Central serous retinopathy (CSR) and age-related macular degeneration (ARMD) are conditions that cause a gradual, painless loss of central vision. They do not present with acute pain, sudden vision loss, or pupillary abnormalities like a vertically oval pupil.

 

Option B. Cataract: Cataracts cause a gradual, painless decrease in vision due to the clouding of the lens. They do not cause sudden vision loss, pain, or changes in pupil shape.

 

Option C. Optic neuritis: Optic neuritis is an inflammation of the optic nerve that can cause sudden vision loss and pain, particularly with eye movement. However, it does not cause changes in the shape of the pupil or a vertically oval pupil. The pain in optic neuritis is typically associated with eye movements rather than the constant severe pain seen in angle closure glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute angle closure glaucoma is characterized by sudden, painful vision loss, and a mid-dilated, vertically oval, sluggishly reacting pupil. Recognizing these signs is crucial for prompt diagnosis and treatment to prevent permanent vision loss.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions, hysteroscopy can be done? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Asherman syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Hysteroscopy is the treatment of choice in Asherman syndrome.

 

Asherman Syndrome

 

  • These are intra-uterine adhesions
  • They usually follow a history of sharp curettage
  • Symptoms are hypomenorrhea, secondary amenorrhoea and secondary infertility

 

Diagnosis –

 

TVS: broken/ irregular endometrium

 

HSG: space filling defect is seen (moth eaten appearance)

 

Ix of choice: Hysteroscopy

 

Treatment - Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tubal ligation: Tubal ligation is done via laparoscopy.

 

Option C. Endocervical polyp: In Endocervical polyps’ cases surgical ligation and excision can be done if severe bleeding is expected. Hysteroscopy can help visualisation and assessment but it is not the primary method for managing endocervical polyps.

 

Option D. Subserosal fibroid: In cases of Subserosal fibroids an MRI helps in detailed mapping of the fibroids if a myomectomy is planned.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hysteroscopy is the treatment of choice in Asherman syndrome.

questions.text: A teenage patient presented with a history of dysmenorrhea and chronic pelvic pain. On ultrasonography, a transverse vaginal septum was seen. Which of the following is she likely to have? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Endometriosis

 

Endometriosis:

 

  • A transverse vaginal septum is a type of Mullerian anomaly, which can be low, mid, or high and can be complete or incomplete.
  • It can present as primary amenorrhea with cyclical abdominal pain if complete.
  • The obstruction to blood flow caused by a transverse vaginal septum can lead to the accumulation of blood in the vagina (hematocolpos) and uterus (hematometra), which can subsequently cause retrograde menstruation and result in endometriosis.
  • The chronic pelvic pain and dysmenorrhea in this patient are consistent with endometriosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tubo-ovarian abscess: Tubo-ovarian abscess is typically associated with pelvic inflammatory disease and presents with fever, lower abdominal pain, and a tender adnexal mass. It is not directly related to Mullerian anomalies like a transverse vaginal septum.

 

Option C. Dermoid cyst: Dermoid cysts (mature cystic teratomas) are benign ovarian tumors that typically do not cause dysmenorrhea or chronic pelvic pain related to menstrual obstruction. They are not associated with Mullerian anomalies.

 

Option D. Theca lutein cyst: Theca lutein cysts are often associated with high levels of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) and are seen in conditions like molar pregnancy and multiple gestations. They do not cause symptoms related to menstrual obstruction and are not associated with Mullerian anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transverse vaginal septum, a Mullerian anomaly, can cause obstruction to menstrual flow leading to hematocolpos, hematometra, and endometriosis, presenting with dysmenorrhea and chronic pelvic pain.

 

Ref: Page no 34, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

choices.text: Wide local excision with frozen border

questions.text: A 55-year-old farmer presents with an ulcer on his neck, and a biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) with negative lymph nodes. What is the most appropriate management strategy for this patient? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Wide local excision with radiation 

 

When managing squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the skin, especially in areas exposed to high levels of sun, such as the neck, the treatment approach may vary based on the size, depth, and location of the tumor as well as the patient's overall health. 

 

This is often the preferred treatment for SCC with a high risk of recurrence or metastasis. The tumor is excised with a margin of normal tissue, and radiation is used to kill any remaining cancer cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radiotherapy: This can be used as a primary treatment for SCC, especially if surgery is not possible, but it is more commonly used adjuvantly (following surgery) if there are high-risk features.

 

Option C. Wide local excision with frozen border: This refers to excision with immediate pathological examination (frozen section) to ensure clear margins. This is a good option for ensuring complete removal during surgery, but adjuvant radiation may still be recommended based on the tumor's features.

 

Option D. Skin grafting: This is a reconstructive procedure used after the removal of the tumor if the defect is too large to close primarily. It does not treat the cancer itself but is a part of the reconstructive process after excision.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The most appropriate management strategy for squamous cell carcinoma of the neck with negative lymph nodes is wide local excision to remove the tumor completely, often followed by radiotherapy to address any potential microscopic residual disease.

choices.text: Check shunt patency by nuclear study
Blood culture and take CSF sample from shunt tap
Blood culture and take CSF sample by lumbar puncture

questions.text: A young child with congenital hydrocephalus was treated with a successful ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt. Four months post surgical repair, the child presented with fever, nuchal rigidity, and irritability. You suspect meningitis. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Blood culture and take CSF sample from shunt tap

 

The most appropriate next step for a child with a VP shunt who presents with symptoms suspicious for meningitis is to obtain blood cultures and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) samples from the shunt tap and/or lumbar puncture. It is important to diagnose and treat meningitis quickly in patients with VP shunts, as untreated meningitis can cause shunt malfunction and other complications.

 

The diagnosis of meningitis in a child with a VP shunt requires obtaining blood cultures and CSF samples. Blood cultures are needed to identify the causative organism, while CSF samples are used to confirm the diagnosis and determine the severity of the infection. CSF can be obtained either through a shunt tap or a lumbar puncture, depending on the child's clinical status and the availability of the appropriate resources.

 

VP shunt fluid is usually obtained from a reservoir that is easily accessible subcutaneously. After sterile preparation, the reservoir should be punctured with a 25-gauge needle. The risk of introducing infection is also low (4.1%).

 

 

Ventriculoperitoneal shunt:

 

 

A ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt is used to drain excess cerebrospinal fluid (CS) due to an obstruction in the normal outflow or there is a decreased absorption of the fluid.

 

Complications of the shunting procedure include the following:

 

  • Infection due to skin flora entering the shunt, usually from Staphylococcus epidermidis
  • Intracerebral or intraventricular hemorrhage
  • Shunt over drainage (slit ventricles)
  • Shunt nephritis
  • Shunt disconnection
  • Shunt obstruction
  • Inguinal hernia

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wait and watch: as the patient is showing features of complication, wait and watch will not be the appropriate answer.

 

Option B. Check shunt patency by nuclear study: we should check the patency of the shunt but as the patient is showing signs of meningitis we should do a CSF analysis by shunt tap.

 

Option C. Blood culture and take CSF sample by lumbar puncture: the main source of infection is from the shunt, so taking CSF sample from there is best.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best step for a child with a VP shunt showing signs of meningitis is to perform a blood culture and obtain a CSF sample from the shunt tap.

questions.text: The strict anaerobe among the following is: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Prevotella

 

The strict anaerobe in the given options is Prevotella.

 

Prevotella spp are anaerobic, gram negative bacilli or coccobacilli.

 

Prevotella spp. are members of the oral, vaginal, and gut microbiota and are often recovered from anaerobic infections of the respiratory tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Burkholderia cepacia:  Is gram-negative, aerobic bacilli belonging to pseudomonad group.

 

Option B. Yersinia enterocolitica: Are gram negative facultative anaerobes.

 

Option C. Stenotrophomonas maltophilia: Are gram-negative, aerobic bacilli belonging to pseudomonad group.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prevotella species are strict anaerobes, thriving in oxygen-free environments, and are part of the normal flora of the oral, vaginal, and gut microbiota. They can be involved in various anaerobic infections, particularly of the respiratory tract.

questions.text: What is the proportion of disease occurrence among those who were exposed compared to those who were not exposed? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Relative risk 

 

The ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).

 

 

Interpretation of RR

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Attributable risk (AR):  is the difference in the risk of disease between the exposed and non-exposed groups, and represents the proportion of disease that can be attributed to the exposure.

 

Option B. Odds ratio (OR):  is the ratio of the odds of disease in the exposed group to the odds of disease in the non-exposed group.

 

Option D. Population attributable risk (PAR):  is the proportion of disease cases in the population that can be reduced if risk factor is modified or eliminated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Relative Risk (RISK RATIO) is used to estimate risk of disease (calculated as incidence of that disease) with exposure to a factor
  • Relative risk (RR) IS A BETTER ESTIMATE of strength of association than Attributable risk (AR)
  • Strength of association:
    • Relative risk (cohort study)
    • Odds ratio (case control study)

questions.text: Identify the image? (INCET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subperiosteal abscess

 

The image shown is a cross-sectional CT scan of the head, particularly focusing on the orbit which is highlighting an abnormal finding adjacent to the orbit, which is indicative of a subperiosteal abscess.

 

Subperiosteal Abscess is forms between the orbit's periosteum (a dense layer of vascular connective tissue covering the bones) and the bone. It is usually a complication of sinusitis, especially ethmoid sinusitis, which can lead to infection spreading to the orbital area. On the CT scan, it appears as a localized bulge or collection adjacent to the bone, as shown in the image. This is consistent with the marking on the image indicating a crescent-shaped fluid collection that deforms the normal contour of the orbit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Orbital Cellulitis: This condition involves inflammation and infection of the soft tissues of the orbit behind the orbital septum. However, orbital cellulitis typically involves more diffuse inflammation that would visibly impact more of the orbital tissue on imaging.

 

Option C. Preseptal Cellulitis: This infection involves the eyelid and skin anterior to the orbital septum, without affecting the orbit itself. The condition would not typically show significant findings behind the orbital septum on a CT scan, as seen in the image.

 

Option D. Sinusitis Only: While sinusitis, the inflammation of the sinus linings, can lead to complications such as a subperiosteal abscess, sinusitis itself would typically show thickened sinus linings and air-fluid levels within the sinus cavities on a CT scan, without necessarily involving the orbit unless complicated by adjacent infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subperiosteal Abscess is crucial because it requires prompt treatment to prevent potential complications, including vision loss and intracranial spread of infection. Management typically involves antibiotics and may require surgical intervention to drain the abscess.

choices.text: Coxsackie viral meningitis and Hand Foot Mouth disease

questions.text: A child presents with fever and vesicular lesions on the upper limb and the lower limb. Neck stiffness was present. Similar lesions were present on the palms, soles, and oral cavity. CSF analysis revealed normal glucose levels and elevated lymphocytes and protein. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coxsackie viral meningitis and Hand Foot Mouth disease

 

The clinical vignette and images provided suggest HFMD meningitis.

 

The presence of vesicular lesions on the palms, soles, and oral cavity, as well as images of the lesions, suggest Hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD). The presence of neck stiffness, as well as CSF with normal glucose levels, elevated lymphocytes, and protein levels, suggests viral meningitis.

 

Therefore the best answer is - Coxsackie viral meningitis and Hand Foot Mouth disease

 

Hand-foot-and-mouth disease:

 

Causes:

 

  • Hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD) is commonly caused by coxsackievirus A16 which is a subgroup of enteroviruses.
  • In large outbreaks, other enteroviruses like enterovirus71, coxsackie A viruses 5,6,7,9, 10 and coxsackie B virus 2 and 5 may also cause HFMD.

 

Clinical features: HFMD is often a minor condition.

 

  • The tongue, posterior pharynx, buccal mucosa, palate, lips, etc. may all have vesicular lesions.
  • Lesions that are maculopapular, vesicular, or pustular may appear on the hands, fingers, buttocks, or groin.
  • Compared to the feet, lesions are more frequently found on the hands.
  • These vesicles disappear within a week.
  • Enterovirus 71 infections are more serious and are linked to cardiovascular and neurological symptoms.
  • Complications from coxsackievirus A16 infections might occasionally include shock, encephalitis, acute flaccid paralysis, and myocarditis.
  • A severe variant of HFMD called atypical HFMD is caused by coxsackievirus A6.

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • HFMD is usually diagnosed clinically by the characteristic lesions.
  • Viral culture can be done to confirm the presence of enterovirus. Blood, CSF, urine, and mucosal swabs can be cultured.
  • RT-PCR testing to detect the viral genome is more sensitive and specific.
  • PCR testing of CSF in children with meningitis is frequently positive even when the cultures are negative.

 

Treatment:

 

  • No specific antiviral agent is proven to be effective against enteroviruses. Supportive care is the mainstay of treatment.
  • Milrinone is suggested as an effective agent for enterovirus 71 cardiopulmonary disease.
  • Immunoglobulins have been used to manage severe cases but with varying outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial meningitis with sepsis: Bacterial meningitis with sepsis is not a likely differential diagnosis for vesicular lesions with this distribution. HSV encephalitis manifests with typical findings of injury to the frontal or parietal cortex or limbic system, including anosmia, memory loss, focal seizures, expressive aphasia, and peculiar behaviour.

 

Option C. Herpes simplex gingivostomatitis and meningoencephalitis: Despite having vesicular lesions, meningoencephalitis and herpes simplex gingivostomatitis show differently clinically. High-grade fever, rapid onset of excruciating mouth pain, and saliva dribbling are the symptoms of HSV gingivostomatitis.

 

Option D. Tuberculous meningitis: Tuberculous meningitis is improbable given the absence of a history of exposure to TB. CSF results in bacterial meningitis often include reduced glucose and raised neutrophils and protein levels. In most cases, CSF results in tuberculous meningitis demonstrate decreased glucose and high amount

 

The majority of the time, CSF results in tuberculous meningitis demonstrate decreased glucose levels, increased lymphocytes, and protein levels.

 

  • Other possible differentials for vesicular lesions include hand-foot-and-mouth disease, varicella (chickenpox), and herpangina.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coxsackie viral infection can cause Hand-foot-and-mouth disease with associated viral meningitis, characterized by vesicular lesions on the palms, soles, and oral cavity, along with normal glucose and elevated lymphocytes in CSF.

questions.text: Which of the following is an adverse effect associated with the long-term use of intermittent teriparatide for the treatment of osteoporosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteosarcoma

 

Teriparatide is a recombinant form of parathyroid hormone (PTH) used as an anabolic (bone-building) agent in the treatment of osteoporosis. It is administered via daily subcutaneous injections. While effective in increasing bone mass and reducing fracture risk, the long-term use of teriparatide has been associated with certain risks.

 

Osteosarcoma is a type of bone cancer that has been linked to the long-term use of teriparatide in animal studies. Specifically, when used for more than two years, there is evidence from these studies suggesting an increased risk of developing osteosarcoma. This potential risk has led to a restriction on the duration of teriparatide therapy to a maximum of two years.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteonecrosis of the jaw bone: This condition is a known adverse effect of bisphosphonates, not teriparatide. Bisphosphonates can lead to decreased blood flow to the jawbone, causing osteonecrosis, especially following dental procedures.

 

Option C. Subtrochanteric fracture (atypical femoral fracture): This type of fracture is also associated with long-term use of bisphosphonates, rather than teriparatide. Bisphosphonates may alter bone remodeling, leading to atypical fractures.

 

Option D. Loss of bone mass: Teriparatide is an anabolic agent that actually increases bone mass. Bisphosphonates also prevent bone mass loss by inhibiting osteoclast-mediated bone resorption. Thus, loss of bone mass is not associated with either teriparatide or bisphosphonates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The long-term use of teriparatide is associated with an increased risk of osteosarcoma, which is why its use is limited to a maximum of two years.

questions.text: A patient had fever and sore throat for which he was started on antibiotic treatment. He develops abdominal pain. He has eosinophiluria and also has WBC casts in his urine. What is the likely diagnosis of the patient? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tubulointerstitial nephritis

 

Tubulointerstitial nephritis, also known as acute allergic interstitial nephritis, is often caused by an allergic reaction to medications such as antibiotics. In this scenario, the patient had a fever and sore throat and was subsequently treated with antibiotics, likely from the penicillin group. Penicillin and other beta-lactam antibiotics are common culprits in causing type 1 hypersensitivity reactions, leading to the presence of eosinophils in the urine (eosinophiluria). This condition is also associated with the presence of WBC casts in the urine, indicating inflammation of the renal interstitium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis: This condition typically presents with RBC casts rather than WBC casts and does not involve eosinophiluria. It follows a streptococcal infection and involves immune complex deposition in the glomeruli.

 

Option C. Lupus nephritis: Lupus nephritis is characterized by immune complex deposition in the glomeruli, leading to glomerulonephritis. It is not typically associated with eosinophiluria and primarily presents with RBC casts.

 

Option D. Rhabdomyolysis: Rhabdomyolysis involves the breakdown of muscle tissue, leading to the release of muscle contents into the bloodstream, including myoglobin, which can cause renal damage. It is characterized by elevated creatine kinase levels and does not present with eosinophiluria or WBC casts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tubulointerstitial nephritis can present with eosinophiluria and WBC casts in the urine, often following antibiotic treatment, particularly with beta-lactam antibiotics. This condition results from an allergic reaction causing inflammation in the renal interstitium.

questions.text: Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities is not a feature of refeeding syndrome? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyperkalemia

 


Refeeding syndrome occurs when a person who has been malnourished starts to eat again. This condition is characterized by metabolic and electrolyte imbalances caused by a sudden shift from a catabolic state (where the body breaks down tissue for energy) to an anabolic state (where the body builds tissue). When refeeding begins, there is an increase in glucose intake, which leads to increased insulin secretion.

 

Hyperkalemia is not a feature of refeeding syndrome. In fact, the opposite occurs (hypokalemia) due to the insulin-mediated intracellular shift of potassium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypophosphatemia: Insulin promotes the uptake of glucose and the subsequent metabolic processes that require phosphate. As phosphate is consumed in the generation of ATP and other metabolic pathways, its levels in the blood decrease, leading to hypophosphatemia.

 

Option B. Hypokalemia: Insulin also drives potassium into cells. As potassium moves intracellularly, the serum potassium levels drop, resulting in hypokalemia.

 

Option D. Hypomagnesemia: Magnesium is a crucial cofactor for many enzymatic reactions, especially those involving ATP. As the metabolic rate increases, magnesium is used up, leading to hypomagnesemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Refeeding syndrome is characterized by hypophosphatemia, hypokalemia, and hypomagnesemia, not hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, nocturnal cough, breathlessness, and wheezing for 4 weeks. Absolute eosinophil count > 5000/μL. Chest X-ray shows a miliary pattern. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia

 

Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia (TPE) is a condition caused by the presence of microfilariae in the pulmonary circulation, leading to a severe immune response characterized by significant eosinophilia. The clinical presentation includes fever, nocturnal cough, breathlessness, and wheezing, which are symptoms consistent with TPE. The absolute eosinophil count greater than 5000/μL further supports this diagnosis.

 

The chest X-ray finding of a miliary pattern, though more commonly associated with tuberculosis, can also be seen in TPE due to the diffuse infiltration of eosinophils in the lungs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchial asthma: Asthma can present with wheezing and nocturnal symptoms but is not typically associated with a miliary pattern on chest X-ray or such a high level of eosinophilia.

 

Option B. Miliary tuberculosis: Miliary tuberculosis can present with a miliary pattern on chest X-ray but is not associated with a significantly elevated eosinophil count. Miliary TB usually presents with systemic symptoms like weight loss, night sweats, and widespread dissemination in the body.

 

Option D. Hypersensitivity pneumonitis: This condition can cause pulmonary symptoms and may present with a miliary pattern on imaging. However, it is usually a type III hypersensitivity reaction (immune complex-mediated) and does not typically lead to such high levels of eosinophilia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia is characterized by symptoms like fever, nocturnal cough, breathlessness, wheezing, significant eosinophilia, and a miliary pattern on chest X-ray. This diagnosis should be considered in patients presenting with these clinical findings, especially in endemic regions. The treatment of choice for TPE is diethylcarbamazine (DEC).

questions.text: Gastric lavage can be performed in case of poisoning by: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Carbolic acid

 

Gastric lavage can be performed in case of carbolic poisoning. It is a corrosive acid, but it hardens the Gl mucosa thus anesthetizing its nerve endings and allows for gastric lavage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sulphuric acid: A concentrated inorganic acid that can cause severe corrosion and softening of the stomach wall, making gastric lavage dangerous due to the risk of perforation.

 

Option B. Strychnine: A convulsive poison that increases the risk of aspiration during seizures, making gastric lavage unsafe.

 

Option D. Kerosene oil: A volatile hydrocarbon that poses a significant risk of aspiration pneumonitis if gastric lavage is performed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Contraindications to gastric lavage:

 

  1. Corrosive poisons such as concentrated inorganic acids (e.g. sulfuric acid, nitric acid etc.) corrode and soften the stomach wall, making it prone for perforation (exception carbolic acid which hardens the stomach wall and gastric lavage is done safely).
  2. Risk of aspiration: Convulsive poisons, Comatose patients, Volatile poisons (hydrocarbons like kerosene)
  3. Upper gastrointestinal tract diseases: Example oesophageal varices
  4. Hypothermia
  5. Hemorrhagic diathesis

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a feature in cerebral palsy? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Flaccid paralysis

 

Flaccid paralysis is not a feature of cerebral palsy (CP). It is a feature of lower motor neuron disease.

 

Cerebral palsy is characterized by abnormalities in muscle tone and movement, including -

 

  • Hypertonia (increased muscle tone),
  • Hypotonia (decreased muscle tone),
  • Ataxia (lack of muscle coordination) is also commonly observed in individuals with cerebral palsy.
  • A deficit in the motor, language, and social milestones
  • Microcephaly is a feature of cerebral palsy because of the insult to the developing brain.
  • It is an upper motor neuron disease characterized by rigidity and scissoring gait.
  • Spastic CP is the commonest type (65%)

 

Seen in conditions such as Guillain-Barré syndrome, transverse myelitis, poliomyelitis, and traumatic neuritis, but not typically in cerebral palsy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypotonia: Can be present in cerebral palsy, characterized by low muscle tone.

 

Option B. Microcephaly: Often associated with cerebral palsy due to brain injury or developmental issues.

 

Option C. Ataxia: Characterized by poor balance and coordination, is a common feature of certain types of cerebral palsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flaccid paralysis is not a feature of cerebral palsy; it is indicative of lower motor neuron disease. Cerebral palsy is characterized by various forms of muscle tone abnormalities and movement disorders.

questions.text: In Demographic cycle, B curve represents: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Death rate

 

In the demographic cycle, the B curve represents the death rate (Crude Death Rate - CDR). The demographic cycle is divided into five stages, which are primarily determined by birth and death rates:

 

  1. Stage 1 (High Stationary): Both the birth rate (A) and the death rate (B) are high, resulting in a stable population.
  2. Stage 2 (Early Expanding): The birth rate (A) remains high while the death rate (B) starts to decline due to improved medical facilities, causing the population to increase.
  3. Stage 3 (Late Expanding): Both birth and death rates start declining, often due to the introduction of family planning and other socio-economic factors. India is currently in this stage.
  4. Stage 4 (Low Stationary): Both rates decline to a low level, stabilizing the population growth.
  5. Stage 5 (Declining): The birth rate drops below the death rate, leading to a reduction in population size.

 

In this context, Curve B clearly represents the death rate as it follows the pattern of decline in stages 2 and 3, stabilizes in stage 4, and may increase slightly in stage 5.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Birth rate: Incorrect. Curve A represents the birth rate (Crude Birth Rate - CBR), which remains high initially but starts to decline from stage 3 onwards.

 

Option C. Growth rate: Incorrect. Growth rate is not directly shown on the graph; it is inferred from the difference between birth and death rates.

 

Option D. Total population: Incorrect. Curve C represents the total population, which increases as the death rate declines and stabilizes when both rates are low.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The B curve in the demographic cycle represents the death rate, which declines significantly from stage 2 due to improved healthcare and stabilizes in later stages.

questions.text: Which of the following mechanism in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle is mainly responsible for the resorption of divalent ions? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Paracellular Transport

 

Paracellular Transport in the thick ascending limb of loop of Henle is responsible for the resorption of divalent ions such as, calcium, magnesium, etc.

 

The sodium-potassium ATPase pump in the basolateral cell membrane maintains a low intracellular sodium concentration and a negative electrical potential in the cell.

 

The 1-sodium, 2-chloride, 1-potassium co-transporter in the luminal membrane transports these three ions from the tubular lumen into the cells, using the potential energy released by diffusion of sodium down an electrochemical gradient into the cells.

 

Sodium is also transported into the tubular cell by sodium-hydrogen counter-transport.

 

The positive charge (+8 mV) due to slight back leak of potassium ions into the lumen of the tubular lumen relative to the interstitial fluid forces cations such as Mg++ and Ca++ to diffuse from the lumen to the interstitial fluid via the paracellular pathway.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary active: Incorrect. This involves direct use of ATP for ion transport, not the main mechanism for divalent ion resorption in the thick ascending limb.

 

Option B. Secondary Active: Incorrect. While secondary active transport is important for moving ions, it is not the primary mechanism for divalent ion resorption here.

 

Option D. Transcellular Transport: Incorrect. Transcellular transport involves movement through the cell, whereas divalent ion resorption primarily occurs via the paracellular pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paracellular transport in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle is the main mechanism responsible for the resorption of divalent ions such as calcium and magnesium, driven by the positive luminal charge and facilitated by the sodium-potassium ATPase pump and co-transporters.

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image:(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ankyloblepharon

 

Ankyloblepharon is a condition where the upper and lower eyelids become attached to each other. This can happen as a congenital anomaly or due to adhesions that form during the healing process of traumatic wounds, ulcers, or chemical burns affecting the eyelid margins. Treatment involves removing the adhesions between the eyelid margins. In cases where adhesions extend to the angles, epithelial grafts should be used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Symblepharon is the adhesion between the palpebral and bulbar conjunctiva in which the eyelids become adherent to the eyeball.

 

The image given below shows symblepharon.

 

 

Option C: Congenital blepharophimosis is a condition in which the extent of the palpebral fissure is decreased. It can be congenital or acquired and is due to a vertical skin fold at the lateral canthus. No treatment is required. In some cases, canthoplasty is done.

 

 

Option D: Congenital ptosis is a condition present since birth and is characterized by drooping of one or both upper eyelids due to developmental defects or weakness of the levator palpebrae superioris (LPS) muscle. The affected individuals may also have lid lag on downward gaze. The most common treatment for congenital ptosis is surgical correction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ankyloblepharon involves the fusion of the eyelid margins, which can be congenital or acquired, and requires surgical intervention to correct the adhesion and restore normal eyelid function and appearance.

questions.text: Which of the following has a poor prognosis with exposure and response prevention in OCD? ( NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hoarding

 

Among the OCD subtypes, hoarding has shown to be more resistant to treatment with ERP. This might be because individuals with hoarding disorder often do not recognize their behavior as problematic and may lack insight into the disorder.

 

Exposure and response prevention (ERP) is a type of cognitive-behavioral therapy that is effective for many individuals with obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). However, certain subtypes or themes of OCD might respond less effectively to ERP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pathological doubt: While challenging, ERP can be tailored to address pathological doubt by creating exposures that trigger doubt without seeking reassurance.

 

Option B. Magical thinking: ERP can also be adapted for magical thinking by exposing the individual to the feared situation or thought without engaging in the ritualistic behavior.

 

Option D. Contamination obsession: Contamination fears are typically one of the subtypes that respond quite well to ERP, as the therapist can create direct exposures involving the feared contaminant.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Hoarding disorder is characterised by acquiring and not being able to discard things that are considered to have little or no use. This will lead to cluttering of house, to an extent that it becomes unsafe to live. This disorder is driven by fear of losing something important. Treatment includes SSRIs and CBT.  Hoarding disorder tends to have a poorer prognosis with exposure and response prevention compared to other subtypes.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 431.

questions.text: Which of the following decreases in inflammation? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Albumin

 

During inflammation, various proteins called acute phase reactants change their serum concentrations. These reactants are divided into positive and negative acute phase reactants based on whether their levels increase or decrease in response to inflammation.

 

Negative acute phase reactants decrease during inflammation. These include:

 

(Mnemonic: RATT)

 

  • Retinol-binding protein (RBP): This protein also decreases during inflammation.
  • Albumin: Its levels decrease during acute and chronic inflammation as part of the body's response to redistribute amino acids for the production of positive acute phase proteins.
  • Transferrin: Its levels also decrease during inflammation.
  • Transthyretin (prealbumin): Another negative acute phase reactant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CRP (C-reactive protein): CRP is a positive acute phase reactant that increases during inflammation. It is commonly used as a marker to assess the presence and intensity of an inflammatory response.

 

Option B. Hepcidin: Hepcidin is another positive acute phase reactant that increases during inflammation. It plays a role in regulating iron metabolism.

 

Option D. Ferritin: Ferritin is a positive acute phase reactant that increases in response to inflammation. It serves as an indicator of body iron stores and also rises during inflammatory states.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Albumin is a negative acute phase reactant that decreases during inflammation, while CRP, hepcidin, and ferritin are positive acute phase reactants that increase.

questions.text: A patient came to the emergency department with a history of being involved in a road traffic accident, resulting in a fracture of the femur shaft. The patient's condition was promptly stabilized. However, after a period of 12 hours, the individual experienced a sudden onset of difficulty breathing, confusion, and the appearance of small reddish-purple skin rashes (petechiae) over the chest and underarm areas. What potential diagnosis could explain these symptoms? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Fat embolism

 

  • The probable diagnosis derived from the given clinical scenario can be fat embolism.
  • Fat embolism although should be diagnosed with trauma to long bone, usually Femur and clinical presentation of pulmonary involvement, CNS depression and skin involvement (Petechiae).

 

FAT EMBOLISM SYNDROME

 

  • Fat embolism refers to the presence of fat globules in vital organs and peripheral circulation after fracture of a long bone or other major trauma.
  • Fat embolism syndrome reflects a serious systemic manifestation as a consequence to these emboli.
  • Fat embolism is more commonly seen in patients with multiple fractures and in fractures involving lower limbs especially femur.
  • Fat originates from the site of trauma, particularly from the injured marrow. Fat globules > 10 mm are considered significant.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Early warning signs are a slight rise in temperature and pulse rate (tachycardia).
    • The classical triad of fat embolism syndrome is:
      1. Respiratory symptoms: Dyspnea or tachypnea
      2. Neurological symptoms: Confusion or disorientation
      3. Petechial rash: In axilla, neck, periumbilical area, conjunctiva of lower lid, front and back of chest, shoulder
  • Diagnostic Criterion for Fat Embolism:

 

 

  • 1 major + 4 minor = Fat embolism

 

  • Prevention:
    • Fracture stabilization
    • Removing fat emboli from circulation by:
      • Lipolytic agents as heparin (increase serum lipase activity)
      • Hypertonic glucose (decrease FFA production)
  • Offset its effect by:
    • Dextran (expand plasma volume, reduces RBC aggregation and platelet adherence)
    • Aprotinin (protease inhibitor) – decreases platelet aggregation and serotonin release
    • Alcohol has vasodilator and lipolytic effect.
  • Treatment:
    • The aim of treatment is maintaining adequate oxygen level in the blood. If necessary, by using intermittent positive pressure ventilation. Oxygen is the only therapeutic tool of proven use.
    • It should be administered in sufficient amount to maintain arterial PO2 > 80 mm Hg. O2 toxicity (pneumonitis) is avoided by using O2 conc. below 40%.
    • Steroids are given to Avoid Pneumonitis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Head injury. Based on the mechanism, head trauma is classified as blunt (the most common mechanism), penetrating (most fatal), and blast. Most severe TBIs result from motor vehicle collisions and falls. A good history concerning the mechanism of injury is important. GCS is used to describe the level of consciousness. A patient with mild head injury may present with swelling from a bump or a bruise, small, superficial cut in the scalp, headache, sensitivity to noise and light, irritability, confusion, dizziness, balance problems, nausea, problems with memory and/or concentration, blurred vision, tinnitus. Moderate to severe head injury symptoms may include any of the above plus loss of consciousness, severe headache that does not go away, repeated nausea and vomiting, loss of short-term memory, such as difficulty remembering the events that led right up to and through the traumatic event, slurred speech, difficulty with walking, weakness in one side or area of the body, sweating, pale skin, seizures, blood or clear fluid draining from the ears or nose, one pupil  is dilated, or looks larger, than the other eye and doesn't constrict, or get smaller, when exposed to light , deep cut or laceration in the scalp, open wound in the head, foreign object penetrating the head, coma.

 

Option C. Blunt trauma to chest. Chest trauma remains a serious problem in high-speed vehicle accidents. Thoracic trauma occurs in approximately 60% patients and has a mortality of 20-25%. The mortality rate in blunt chest trauma may be due to pulmonary and non-pulmonary complications. In the primary survey of chest trauma patients, 6 life-threatening conditions (airway obstruction, tension pneumothorax, open pneumothorax, massive hemothorax, flail chest, pericardial tamponade) should be immediately investigated and treated. Signs and symptoms of thoracic trauma include cyanosis of fingers, lips or face, dyspnea, tachypnea or bradypnea, contusion, laceration, perforations, distension, hemoptysis, signs of shock (hypoperfusion), tracheal deviation, paradoxical movement of the chest wall, distended jugular veins, decreased or absent breathing sounds, pain, failure of chest expansion in normal inspiration. Respiratory distress is a serious problem and the patients may breathe with nasal flaring, using accessory muscles, intercostal and subcostal retractions, and tachypnea. The patient's lungs may not be equally involved in breathing. Paradoxical respiration can be observed and immediate diagnosis of flail chest can be made.

 

Option D. Hemorrhagic shock. Shock refers to the inadequate perfusion of tissues due to the imbalance between the oxygen demand of tissues and the body’s ability to supply it. Blunt or penetrating trauma is the most common cause, followed by upper and lower gastrointestinal sources. Bleeding may be either external or internal. It occurs due to the depletion of intravascular volume through blood loss to the point of being unable to match the tissues demand for oxygen. As a result, mitochondria are unable to sustain aerobic metabolism for the production of oxygen and switch to the less efficient anaerobic metabolism to meet the cellular demand for adenosine triphosphate which leads to pyruvate production and conversion to lactic acid to maintain some degree of cellular respiration. The body compensates by increasing heart rate and contractility, followed by baroreceptor activation resulting in sympathetic nervous system activation and peripheral vasoconstriction. Signs and symptoms include blue lips and finger nails, low or no urine output, excessive sweating, shallow breathing, dizziness or loss of consciousness, confusion, chest pain, low blood pressure, rapid heart rate, weak pulse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • History of a road traffic accident, resulting in a fracture of the femur shaft with appearance of symptoms of sudden onset of difficulty breathing, confusion, and small reddish-purple skin rashes over the chest and underarm areas after a period of 12 hours all indicates fat embolism which needs immediate intervention.

questions.text: What is the causative organism of angular conjunctivitis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Moraxella lacunata

 

  • Moraxella species are gram-negative diplococci that can cause angular conjunctivitis.
  • Angular conjunctivitis is characterized by inflammation of the inner and outer canthi, skin excoriation, and a collection of dirty-white, foamy discharge at the angles.
  • Moraxella axenfeld, Moraxella lacunata, and Moraxella catarrhalis are common causes of angular conjunctivitis, while Staphylococcus aureus is a rare cause.
  • The source of infection is the nasal tract of healthy people and the nasal discharge of patients with angular conjunctivitis.
  • The infection spreads from the nasal cavity to the eye through contaminated hands and handkerchiefs.
  • Oxytetracycline is the preferred treatment for angular conjunctivitis, with a duration of 10 to 14 days.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Haemophilus influenzae: While this organism can cause bacterial conjunctivitis, it is not specifically associated with angular conjunctivitis.

 

Option C. Adenovirus type 32: Adenoviruses can cause viral conjunctivitis, including epidemic keratoconjunctivitis, but they are not the typical cause of angular conjunctivitis.

 

Option D. Coxsackie B virus: This virus can cause viral infections including conjunctivitis, but it is not the usual causative agent for angular conjunctivitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary causative organism of angular conjunctivitis is Moraxella lacunata, which is a gram-negative diplococci. The infection spreads from the nasal cavity to the eyes through contaminated hands and handkerchiefs, and is characterized by inflammation of the canthi and a dirty-white, foamy discharge. The preferred treatment is oxytetracycline for 10 to 14 days.

questions.text: Police brought a person from the railway track with features of dry mouth, dilated pupil, dry skin, slurring of speech, and delirium. What could be the possible diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dhatura


Dhatura poisoning is associated with anticholinergic toxidrome, which presents with features such as dry mouth, dilated pupils, dry skin, slurred speech, and delirium. Anticholinergic substances like Dhatura inhibit the action of acetylcholine, leading to reduced secretions, dilated pupils, and central nervous system effects like confusion and delirium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Morphine: Morphine is an opioid and falls under the category of CNS depressants. Opioids typically cause pupil constriction (miosis), not dilation, and do not produce dry skin or dry mouth, making this option incorrect.

 

Option B. Alcohol: Alcohol, especially in the early stages, may cause pupil dilation but usually presents with wet skin and slurred speech due to CNS depression, not dry features. Dry skin and mouth are not characteristic of alcohol intoxication, making this option incorrect.

 

Option C. Cocaine: Cocaine is a sympathomimetic agent, which can cause pupil dilation but does not cause dry mouth or dry skin. Cocaine typically increases body secretions rather than reducing them, so this does not fit the anticholinergic profile described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:


Dhatura poisoning exhibits an anticholinergic toxidrome characterized by dry mouth, dry skin, dilated pupils, and altered mental status, distinguishing it from other toxidromes.

questions.text: What is anisometropia? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Difference in refractive error

 

Anisometropia refers to a condition where there is a significant difference in the refractive error (i.e., the focusing power) between the two eyes. This difference can cause each eye to focus differently, leading to difficulties in binocular vision and sometimes resulting in amblyopia (lazy eye) if one eye is significantly more affected than the other.

 

  1. ANISOMETROPIA: Difference between Refractive Error of two eyes
  2. ANISEIKONIA: Difference between Image size in two eyes
  3. ANISOCORIA: Difference between Pupil size of two eyes
  4. ANISOPIA: Difference between vision of two eyes

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Difference in color of iris: Incorrect. This condition is called heterochromia, not anisometropia. Heterochromia refers to a difference in coloration, typically of the iris.

 

Option C. Difference in axial length: Incorrect. While differences in axial length can contribute to anisometropia, the term itself specifically refers to differences in refractive error, not just axial length.

 

Option D. Difference in visual acuity: Incorrect. Although anisometropia can lead to differences in visual acuity between the two eyes, the term specifically refers to the difference in refractive error, not visual acuity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anisometropia is defined as a difference in the refractive error between the two eyes, which can lead to difficulties in binocular vision and potentially cause amblyopia in the more affected eye.

questions.text: Which drug induces the following response on blood pressure and heart rate as shown in the given image? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Norepinephrine

 

The above graph shows fall in the heart rate (reflex bradycardia), with rise in the systolic diastolic and mean arterial pressure. Out of the four drugs above, Norepinephrine can produce these effects by its action of alpha-1 and beta-1 receptors.

 

Stimulation of alpha-1 receptors causes vasoconstriction thus raising the blood pressure. Stimulation of Beta 1 receptors increases the heart rate and stroke volume initially but the increase in mean arterial pressure leads to reflex bradycardia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dopamine: acts on alpha, beta and Dopamine receptors depending on its concentration. At higher concentration, dopamine increases systolic blood pressure and pulse pressure.

 

Option B. Epinephrine acts on alpha-1, alpha-2, beta-1 and beta-2 receptors. It increases the SBP and decreases the DBP, thus widened pulse pressure. Consequently, due to cardiac stimulation, heart rate is increased.

 

Option D. Isoproterenol acts on Beta-1, 2 and 3 receptors. It increases the contractility and increases the heart rate due to its beta-1 action. The beta-2 receptors mediate vasodilation, causing fall in mean arterial pressure and reflex tachycardia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Norepinephrine is the drug that induces the observed response of increased systolic, diastolic, and mean arterial pressure along with reflex bradycardia. This is due to its potent alpha-1 mediated vasoconstriction and initial beta-1 stimulation, followed by the baroreceptor reflex reducing heart rate. Other drugs like dopamine, epinephrine, and isoproterenol have different profiles of action and do not produce this specific combination of effects.

questions.text: What is the Child-Turcotte-Pugh (CTP) class for the patient who has a serum bilirubin 2.5 mg/dl, serum albumin 3 g/dL, prothrombin time 5 seconds (INR = 2), no encephalopathy, and mild ascites? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Class B

 

To determine the Child-Turcotte-Pugh (CTP) score, each of the five clinical measures is scored with points from 1 to 3 based on specific criteria:

 

  1. Bilirubin:
    • <2 mg/dL = 1 point
    • 2-3 mg/dL = 2 points (Patient has 2.5 mg/dL)
    • 3 mg/dL = 3 points
  2. Albumin:
    • 3.5 g/dL = 1 point
    • 2.8-3.5 g/dL = 2 points
    • <2.8 g/dL = 3 points (Patient has 3 g/dL, scoring 2 points)
  3. INR:
    • 1-1.7 = 1 point
    • 1.8-2.3 = 2 points (Patient has INR = 2)
    • 2.3 = 3 points
  4. Ascites:
    • None = 1 point
    • Controlled = 2 points (Patient has mild ascites, scoring 2 points)
    • Refractory = 3 points
  5. Encephalopathy:
    • None = 1 point (Patient has none)
    • Grade 1-2 = 2 points
    • Grade 3-4 = 3 points

 

Scoring Calculation:

 

  • Bilirubin = 2 points
  • Albumin = 2 points
  • INR = 2 points
  • Ascites = 2 points
  • Encephalopathy = 1 point
    Total = 9 points

The patient scores 9 points, placing them in Child-Turcotte-Pugh Class B.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Child-Turcotte-Pugh scoring system

 

 

Inference:

 

  • CTP A: 5-6
  • CTP B: 7-9
  • CTP C: 10-15

 

Reference - Harrison/Cirrhosis/Chapter 344

choices.text: EDV and pressure curve shifts to left without change in slope
Slope changes in ESV pressure curve
End systolic volume and pressure curve shifts to left without change in slope
Slope changes in EDV and pressure curve

questions.text:
If the contractility of the heart is decreased, which of the following is seen? (INICET Nov 2021)

 

ESV: End-systolic volume

EDV: End-diastolic volume
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Slope changes in ESV pressure curve

 

A decrease in contractility of the heart can result in changes in the slope of the end-systolic pressure-volume relationship (ESV pressure curve) in addition to changes in end-systolic volume (ESV) and end-diastolic volume (EDV).

 

When contractility is decreased, the ventricle is less able to generate the same pressure for a given volume of blood, resulting in a reduced slope of the ESV pressure curve. This indicates that the heart is less efficient in ejecting blood during systole.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is B. Slope changes in ESV pressure curve. This is because the slope of the ESV pressure curve is an index of contractility, and a decrease in contractility results in a reduced slope of the curve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. is incorrect because a leftward shift of the end-diastolic pressure-volume curve without a change in slope is seen in conditions such as hypertension and aortic stenosis, where the heart has to generate greater pressure to overcome an increased afterload.

 

Option C. is incorrect because a leftward shift of the end-systolic pressure-volume curve without a change in slope is not typically seen in response to changes in contractility.

 

Option D. is incorrect because a change in the slope of the EDV pressure curve is not typically observed in response to changes in contractility.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A decrease in cardiac contractility leads to a decrease in the slope of the end-systolic pressure-volume (ESV) curve, indicating reduced efficiency in blood ejection during systole.

questions.text: All of the following are AIDS defining illnesses except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Oral Candidiasis

 

Oral candidiasis, while commonly associated with HIV infection, is not itself an AIDS-defining illness. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) list of AIDS-defining illnesses includes more severe manifestations such as candidiasis of the esophagus, trachea, bronchi, or lungs, but not oral candidiasis. This fungal infection is often seen in patients with HIV as a marker of immune suppression but does not qualify as an indicator of AIDS on its own.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Encephalopathy attributed to HIV: This is an AIDS-defining condition, as it represents a direct effect of HIV on the brain resulting in cognitive impairment and motor dysfunction.

 

Option B. Invasive cervical cancer: This is considered an AIDS-defining illness due to the high risk and prevalence of this cancer in individuals with advanced HIV, reflecting a significant degree of immunosuppression.

 

Option C. Mycobacterium tuberculosis of any site: Tuberculosis, whether pulmonary or extrapulmonary, is an AIDS-defining illness due to its severity and frequency in the context of HIV-induced immune suppression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison/Infectious Disease/Chap 202

questions.text:
Arrange the structures of the cubital fossa in sequence from medial to lateral? (INICET Nov 2022)

 

1. Median nerve

2. Radial nerve

3. Tendon of biceps brachi

4. Brachial artery
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1,4,3,2

 

Explanation:

 

The structures are arranged in the cubital fossa from medial to lateral as follows:

 

1. Median nerve

2. Brachial artery

3. Tendon of biceps brachii

4. Radial nerve (Superficial Branch of radial nerve)

Mnemonic is MBBR
 

 

 

The cubital fossa is actually a triangular area located on the anterior aspect of the elbow, not the upper forearm. It is bounded by several structures, including:

 

  • The lateral border of the pronator teres muscle, which forms the medial boundary
  • The medial border of the brachioradialis muscle, which forms the lateral boundary
  • The imaginary line connecting the epicondyles of the humerus, which forms the superior boundary
  • The floor of the cubital fossa is formed by the brachialis and supinator muscles, while the roof is formed by the Deep fascia of the skin.
  • The roof of cubital fossa contains Subcutaneous veins which are used for routine phlebotomy procedures. These veins are - median cubital vein, cephalic vein and basilic vein

 

The cubital fossa contains several important structures, including the brachial artery, radial nerve, and median nerve. It is a common site for blood draws and intravenous catheter placement due to the relatively superficial location of the structures and ease of access.

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct anatomical sequencing of structures in the cubital fossa from medial to lateral—median nerve, brachial artery, tendon of biceps brachii, and radial nerve—is essential for both anatomical education and practical clinical applications.

questions.text: A patient presents with a clinical scenario of obstructive jaundice. Which of the following results can be seen on Van der Bergh's reaction?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Direct positive

 

In obstructive jaundice, the Van den Bergh reaction may show a positive result for direct bilirubin. Direct bilirubin is also known as conjugated bilirubin, and it is water-soluble. Elevated levels of direct bilirubin in the blood can be an indicator of liver or biliary tract dysfunction, which is often seen in obstructive jaundice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Indirect positive: Indirect bilirubin, also known as unconjugated bilirubin, is typically associated with hemolytic disorders rather than obstructive jaundice. Therefore, in the context of obstructive jaundice, the Van den Bergh reaction may not show a positive result for indirect bilirubin.

 

Option C. Both positive: In the context of obstructive jaundice, it's more common for the Van den Bergh reaction to show a positive result for direct bilirubin (conjugated bilirubin) rather than indirect bilirubin. However, if there is a combination of liver dysfunction and hemolysis, both direct and indirect bilirubin levels may be elevated, resulting in both being positive on the Van den Bergh reaction.

 

Option D. Coproporphyrin: Coproporphyrin is not typically measured using the Van den Bergh reaction. It is a different component related to porphyrin metabolism and is not directly associated with the assessment of bilirubin levels in obstructive jaundice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Van den Bergh reaction is a chemical reaction used to measure bilirubin levels in blood, specifically amount of conjugated bilirubin in the blood.

 

Principle: bilirubin reacts with diazotized sulphanilic acid to produce purple colored azobilirubin. This reaction is highly useful in understanding the nature of jaundice.

 

This test helps to identify the type of jaundice –

 

  1. The serum of the patient is mixed with diazo reagent. If a red color develops immediately, it is called a direct positive. It happens if conjugated bilirubin is present.
  2. In an indirect positive test, the patient's serum is first treated with alcohol and later mixed with diazo reagent. This causes development of a red color. It is seen if unconjugated bilirubin is present.
  3. If both conjugated and unconjugated bilirubin are present the reaction is termed a biphasic reaction.

questions.text: Which of the following is an X-linked disorder? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Color blindness

 

Among the options given, color blindness is an X-linked disorder.

 

Color blindness is a condition in which an individual has difficulty distinguishing between different colors. It is caused by a genetic mutation that affects the development or function of the photopigments in the retina of the eye.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thalassemia: Thalassemia, sickle cell anemia, and cystic fibrosis are not X-linked disorders. They are all Autosomal recessive inheritance. Thalassemia is an inherited blood disorder that affects the production of hemoglobin, a protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen.

 

Option C. Sickle cell anemia: Sickle cell anemia is also an inherited blood disorder that affects the production of hemoglobin, leading to the formation of abnormal, sickle-shaped red blood cells.

 

Option D. Cystic fibrosis: Cystic fibrosis is an inherited disorder that affects the production and function of mucus, leading to the buildup of thick, sticky mucus in the lungs and other organs.

 

These conditions are inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, meaning that both parents must carry a mutated gene to pass the condition on to their children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Color blindness is an X-linked disorder, meaning that the gene causing the condition is located on the X chromosome, which primarily affects males and is passed down from carrier mothers.

questions.text: A teacher demonstrated handwashing procedures to her students. Students repeated the activity later in the day and at home. What kind of learning is going on here? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Psychomotor

 

The scenario described involves the teacher demonstrating a physical skill (handwashing), which the students then practice and replicate. This type of learning pertains to the acquisition of motor skills and involves physical movement and coordination, making it psychomotor learning.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Cognitive: It pertains to mental skills or acquiring knowledge. It involves understanding, reasoning, and thinking processes.

 

Option C. Affective: It relates to feelings, values, attitudes, motivations, and appreciations.

 

Option D. Affective and cognitive: It would involve both emotions/attitudes and mental processes, which is not the primary focus in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Psychomotor learning involves the acquisition and refinement of motor skills and requires physical movement and coordination. It is demonstrated in this scenario by students learning and practicing the handwashing procedure shown by their teacher.

 

Reference: Milde FK. The Function of Feedback in Psychomotor-Skill Learning. Western Journal of Nursing Research. 1988;10(4):425-434.

questions.text:
What characteristics define necrosis among the options provided? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Disrupted cell membrane
  2. Induces inflammation
  3. Swelling of the cell
  4. Can be seen physiologically
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

 

Necrosis is a form of cell injury that results in the premature death of cells in living tissue by autolysis. The following are the key characteristics of necrosis:

 

1. Disrupted cell membrane: Necrosis is characterized by the loss of cell membrane integrity, leading to the uncontrolled release of cellular contents into the extracellular space.

 

2. Induces inflammation: The release of cellular contents into the surrounding tissue causes an inflammatory response. This is a hallmark of necrosis, as the body reacts to the injury.

 

3. Swelling of the cell: In necrosis, cells typically swell and eventually rupture due to the loss of membrane integrity and the influx of water and ions.

 

Other Options:

 

4. Necrosis is never physiological: it always occurs as a result of pathological conditions. Unlike apoptosis, which is a programmed and regulated form of cell death, necrosis is unregulated and is usually detrimental to the organism.

 

Additional Information

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

FEATURES OF NECROSIS

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman from a resource-limited setting presents to a local health camp with complaints of chronic eye irritation and a gritty feeling in her eyes for the past few months. On examination, conjunctival scarring and inward turning of the eyelashes are noted. The physician suspects trachoma and recalls the recommended WHO's SAFE strategy for managing trachoma in endemic areas. What does the "S" in the SAFE strategy stand for in this context? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Surgery 

 

The "S" in the SAFE strategy stands for Surgery, specifically for the correction of trachomatous trichiasis and entropion.

 

The SAFE Strategy for Trachoma:

 

S – Surgery (for correction of trachomatous trichiasis and entropion)

A – Antibiotic (Azithromycin)

F – Facial cleanliness to prevent disease transmission

E - Environmental change to increase access to water and sanitation.

 

Trachoma (rough eye) 

 

A microbial infection of the eye caused due to the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis. It is a contagious disease, that can be easily spread by direct contact with an affected person, by means of their eyes, eyelids, nasal and throat secretions and exchange of used towels and handkerchiefs. 

 

The risk factors of trachoma are poor sanitation, crowded living conditions and lack of routine hygiene practices due to poverty. Moreover, trachoma commonly occurs in children between the ages of 2-5 years, more frequently in adult women than men and in surroundings where flies are rampant, as these can serve as vectors to transmit the bacteria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "S" in the WHO's SAFE strategy for trachoma stands for Surgery.

 

Additional Information

 

Trachoma Treatment

 

  • Treatment of choice for Trachoma: Azithromycin 20 mg/kg oral stat
  • Current WHO recommendations for antibiotic treatment of trachoma:
    • District level prevalence is > 10% in 1-9 years old children: Mass treatment with Azithromycin
    • District level prevalence is 5-10% in 1-9 years old children: Targeted treatment with Azithromycin (the identification and treatment of all members of any family in whom one or more members have follicular trachoma)
    • District level prevalence is < 5% in 1-9 years old children: Azithromycin distribution may not be necessary
  • Mass treatment for Trachoma: [NEW GUIDELINES–WHO]
    • Indication of mass treatment in Trachoma: > 10% prevalence of severe and moderate Trachoma in children < 10 yrs of age
    • Treatment: 1% tetracycline ointment BD for 5 consecutive days each month or OD for 10 days each month for 6 consecutive months, or for 60 consecutive days

 

India declared ‘Trachoma-Free’ in December 2017.

questions.text: A truck driver came with painful genital ulcer and lymph nodes. H/O unprotected sex present. Choose the correct clinical condition: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chancroid

 

Chancroid is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi. It is characterized by painful genital ulcers and painful lymphadenopathy (swollen lymph nodes). The history of unprotected sexual intercourse and the clinical presentation of painful genital ulcers and painful lymph nodes strongly suggest chancroid.

 

  1. Painful genital ulcers: Chancroid typically presents with painful ulcers on the genitalia. These ulcers can be multiple and have irregular, undermined edges.
  2. Painful lymph nodes: The infection often leads to painful, swollen lymph nodes in the inguinal region, which can sometimes suppurate and form buboes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Donovanosis: Also known as granuloma inguinale, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. It presents with painless, beefy-red ulcers that bleed easily, not typically associated with painful lymphadenopathy.

 

Option B. Chancre: A chancre is a painless ulcer that is the primary lesion of syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum. It does not fit the description of painful ulcers and painful lymph nodes.

 

Option C. Herpes: Genital herpes, caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV), presents with painful vesicles that evolve into ulcers. However, the presence of vesicles, rather than ulcers initially, distinguishes herpes from chancroid.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with mental retardation and an inability to walk. The fundoscopy image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Tay-Sachs disease

 

  • The clinical scenario and fundoscopy image suggest the diagnosis of Tay-Sachs disease.
  • Tay-Sachs disease is a lysosomal storage disease caused by the deficiency of hexosaminidase.
  • It presents during infancy with macrocephaly, increased startle reaction, gradual loss of motor skills, and a macular cherry-red spot.
  • Hunter disease is an X-linked disorder that presents with short stature, joint stiffness, and intellectual disability.
  • Hurler syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition that affects multiple organs and presents with corneal clouding, coarse facial features, joint stiffness, skeletal dysplasia, glaucoma, retinal degeneration, and nasal discharge.
  • Gaucher disease is a glycolipid storage disorder that presents with hepatosplenomegaly, mental retardation, and erosion of long bones caused by the deficiency of B-glucosidase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hunter Disease: Hunter disease is an X-linked disorder that presents with short stature, joint stiffness, and intellectual disability. It does not typically present with a cherry-red spot on fundoscopy.

 

Option C. Hurler Syndrome: Hurler syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition that affects multiple organs.

 

  • Presentation:
    • Corneal clouding
    • Coarse facial features
    • Joint stiffness
    • Skeletal dysplasia
    • Glaucoma
    • Retinal degeneration
    • Nasal discharge

 

Option D. Gaucher Disease: Gaucher disease is a glycolipid storage disorder caused by the deficiency of β-glucosidase.

 

  • Presentation:
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Mental retardation
    • Erosion of long bones
    • Cherry-red spot may also be seen, but other clinical features and the typical history of Tay-Sachs make it less likely in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tay-Sachs disease presents in infancy with progressive neurological decline, macrocephaly, increased startle reaction, and a characteristic macular cherry-red spot on fundoscopy. It is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme hexosaminidase A.

 

OTHER CAUSES OF CHERRY RED SPOT.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presented with cough and congestion in the chest. He is a known case of atrial fibrillation (AF) and on examination, he had an irregularly irregular pulse and ECG showed AF with a heart rate of 52/min. His current medications are KCl 10 mEq BID, Triamterene, ASA 100mg/day, Atenolol 50 mg BID, and Clarithromycin. Two months ago, his digoxin levels were 1.5 ng/mL and currently, it rose to 3.4 ng/mL. Which of the following is responsible for such an increase in digoxin levels? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Clarithromycin

 

The patient is experiencing elevated digoxin levels, which is likely due to a drug-drug interaction. Digoxin is a medication used to treat various heart conditions, including atrial fibrillation. It has a narrow therapeutic index, meaning that even small changes in its levels can lead to toxicity.

 

Clarithromycin is a macrolide antibiotic that inhibits the enzyme cytochrome P450 3A4 (CYP3A4). Digoxin is partially metabolized by CYP3A4. When clarithromycin inhibits this enzyme, it can lead to decreased metabolism of digoxin, resulting in elevated digoxin levels and potential toxicity. This interaction can explain the significant increase in the patient's digoxin levels from 1.5 ng/mL to 3.4 ng/mL.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Triamterene: Triamterene is a potassium-sparing diuretic and does not typically interact with digoxin in a way that would cause elevated digoxin levels. It is not known to inhibit the metabolism of digoxin.

 

Option B. KCl: Potassium chloride (KCl) supplementation is often given to prevent hypokalemia, which can enhance the toxic effects of digoxin. However, KCl does not directly interact with digoxin to increase its serum levels. Instead, it helps mitigate digoxin toxicity by maintaining normal potassium levels.

 

Option D. Atenolol: Atenolol is a beta-blocker and does not interact with digoxin to increase its serum levels. While it can affect heart rate, it does not interfere with the metabolism or excretion of digoxin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clarithromycin, by inhibiting CYP3A4, can significantly elevate digoxin levels, leading to toxicity. When prescribing medications, it is essential to consider potential drug-drug interactions, especially with drugs like digoxin that have a narrow therapeutic index.

questions.text: What is the gold standard investigation for the diagnosis of myocarditis? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Endo-myocardial biopsy

 

An endo-myocardial biopsy is the gold standard investigation for the diagnosis of myocarditis.

 

Active myocarditis is characterized by an interstitial inflammatory infiltrate associated with degenerating or apoptotic myocytes.

 

Etiological classification of myocarditis:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Magnetic Resonance Imaging: MRI can be used to detect myocardial inflammation and scarring, but it is not the gold standard. It is useful for non-invasive assessment but cannot definitively diagnose myocarditis without histological confirmation.

 

Option C. Brain Natriuretic Peptide (BNP): BNP is a biomarker used to assess heart failure but is not specific or sensitive for diagnosing myocarditis.

 

Option D. LDH1 to LDH2 ratio: This ratio is sometimes used in the context of myocardial infarction but does not have a role in diagnosing myocarditis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endo-myocardial biopsy remains the gold standard for diagnosing myocarditis, as it allows for direct histopathological examination of myocardial tissue.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1064

questions.text: A person who chronically consumes alcohol and indulged in binge drinking ten days’ back was brought to the hospital. At the presentation, he was unconscious. His Non-Contrast CT scan was normal. His blood glucose came out to be 49 mg/dL. What treatment should be initiated? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) I.m thiamine followed by dextrose

 

Chronic alcohol consumption can lead to thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency due to poor nutritional intake, impaired absorption, and increased requirements. In patients with a history of alcohol dependence who present with hypoglycemia, it is crucial to administer thiamine before giving dextrose. The administration of dextrose without thiamine can precipitate Wernicke's encephalopathy, a serious neurological condition caused by thiamine deficiency. This is because dextrose administration increases the demand for thiamine as it is required for carbohydrate metabolism, thus depleting the already low thiamine reserves.

 

Therefore, thiamine should be given intramuscularly (i.m) first to replenish the body's stores and prevent neurological complications, followed by the administration of dextrose to correct hypoglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Normal Saline: While normal saline can be used to maintain hydration, it does not address the critical issue of hypoglycemia or thiamine deficiency in this patient. It is not the appropriate initial treatment for this clinical scenario.

 

Option C. 5% Dextrose: Administering dextrose alone without prior thiamine administration can worsen thiamine deficiency and precipitate Wernicke’s encephalopathy. Therefore, dextrose alone is not a safe choice in alcohol-dependent patients with hypoglycemia.

 

Option D. 20% Dextrose: Similar to 5% dextrose, administering concentrated dextrose without thiamine can significantly worsen thiamine depletion and increase the risk of neurological complications. Thiamine must be administered first.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with alcohol dependence presenting with hypoglycemia, always administer thiamine before dextrose to prevent the precipitation of Wernicke's encephalopathy.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man from Rajasthan is diagnosed with mixed malaria infection – P. falciparum + P. vivax. Treatment regimen on Day 2 would be: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Primaquine 2.5 mg (6 tablets)

 

In cases of mixed malaria infection involving P. falciparum and P. vivax, the treatment approach differs from that of single-species infections.

 

For mixed infections, the primaquine dose is adjusted to 2.5 mg to target both liver and blood stages effectively, while artesunate is used to clear the parasitemia. Artesunate is typically given for three consecutive days, and the dosage of primaquine is reduced compared to when treating only P. falciparum, where the standard dose would be 7.5 mg. This regimen helps in managing mixed malaria effectively, ensuring both species are adequately targeted.

 

Note –

 

  • For patients from other parts of the country, ACT-SP (artesunate + sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine) plus primaquine is used.
  • For patients from northeast India, artemether-lumefantrine combination therapy is preferred.
  • Primaquine in mixed infections is given for 14 days, while in single infections, it is given only on the second day.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In mixed malaria infections involving P. falciparum and P. vivax, primaquine 2.5 mg is used on Day 2 along with artesunate to effectively treat both species.
